_exec_summary.SummaryText:
4.1 Accidental Release Prevention Policies
The City of Avenal WTP has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as personnel training and
consideration of safety in the design, operation, and maintenance of the Gaseous Chlorine
Disinfection System. The City of Avenal WTP's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substance.

4.2 Stationary Source and Regulated Substance
Chlorine is injected into the water in order to disinfect it and to prevent bacterial growth while the water travels through pipelines. The maximum intended inventory for this facility is approximately 6,000 pounds of chlorine kept in three (3) one-ton containers. Chlorine leak detection and warning is provided by high and low chlorine sensor alarms to control room with an audible and visual alarm system.

4.3 Hazard Assessment Summary/Offsite Consequence Analysis
The Off-site Consequence Analysis must be reviewed every five years or within six months of
process changes or other changes that may significantly affect the results of the Off-site
Consequence Analysis.

Worst-Case Release Scenario Results Summary
Per the CalARP Regulations, one worst-case release scenario has been defined for the Gaseous
Chlorine Disinfection System. The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment documentation.

Alternative Release Scenario Results Summary
Per the CalARP Regulations, one alternative-case release scenario has been defined for the
Gaseous Chlorine Disinfection System. The results can be found in the Hazard Assessment
documentation.

4.4 Risk Considerations
Although the storage and use of chlorine has inherent potential risks and the release scenarios can potentially reach sensitive populations within the community, the City of Avenal WTP has recognized these potential risks and structured its safety programs to make the worst-case type of event non-credible.

In addition to the safety practices of the facility and plant personnel to make the worst case event non-credible, it should also be recognized that there are inherent analysis assumptions that make the results of the atmospheric dispersion analysis appear worse than what would actually be expected during such an event.
In addition to the use of conservative analysis assumptions that over-predict the effects of a potential release, other characteristics of the facility and site serve to minimize the potential risks associated with a chlorine release. The facility has chlorine detectors that activate a SCADA alarm and local audible/visual alarms.

4.5 Accidental Release Prevention Program
As part of the implementation of the CalARP/EPA RMP Program for the Chlorination System, key Prevention Program elements were documented and implemented by  City of Avenal WTP to manage process safety issues associated with the use of chlorine for water treatment. Furthermore, common industry
standards, policies, and procedures are currently utilized to ensure safe practices are being
performed. The facility maximum intended inventory of chlorine is 6,000 lbs. Therefore, the regulated substance is over the 2,500-lbs. threshold for EPA RMP, the 1,500-lbs. threshold for Cal/OSHA PSM and the 100-lbs. state threshold for the CalARP Program. As a result, the chlorine covered process is subject to CalARP Program Level 3, EPA RMP Program Level 3, and Cal/OSHA PSM.

The Prevention Program 3 elements include:
19 CCR § 5100.1 Process Safety Information (PSI)
19 CCR § 5100.2 Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)
19 CCR § 5100.3 Operating Procedures (OP)
19 CCR § 5100.4 Training (TRN)
19 CCR § 5100.5 Mechanical Integrity (MI)
19 CCR § 5100.6 Management of Change (MOC)
19 CCR § 5100.7 Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR)
19 CCR § 5100.8 Compliance Audits (CA)
19 CCR § 5100.9 Incident Investigation (II)
19 CCR § 5100.10 Employee Participation (EP)
19 CCR § 5100.11 Hot Work Permit (HWP)
19 CCR § 5100.12 Cont

ractors (CON)
In addition, key emergency response elements were addressed in the Emergency Response
Program (see 4.7 Emergency Response Program below).

4.6 Five-Year Accident History
There have been no CalARP applicable releases of chlorine or accidents from a release of the
covered process resulting in death, injuries, or significant property damage at City of Avenal WTP in the past five years.

4.7 Emergency Response Program
The City of Avenal WTP personnel are not first responders, in the event of an emergency they would contact local responders. The City of Avenal WTP has submitted a Hazardous Materials Business Plan in order to coordinate with the local emergency planning and response agencies to ensure that in an event of an emergency they are properly prepared and have knowledge of the system.

4.8 External Events Analysis
Pursuant to the requirements of California Code of Regulations, Title 19, Division 5, Chapter 2,
Section 5070.7 (q), general events external to the plant that can conceivably cause a release of
chlorine were addressed by the PHA. Additional seismic assessment evaluations were scheduled to be completed in 2025.

4.9 Planned Changes To Improve Safety
The Compliance Audit has been conducted to examine any deficiencies at the Program 3 facility  improve the safety program. Planned changes to improve safety are listed as recommendations in the 2023 Compliance Audit Report and 2025 PHA Report.

4.10 Flammables: Worst Case
The use of flammable materials at the City of Avenal WTP facility is not encompassed by either the federal or
state RMP requirements. Therefore, this section is not applicable.
4.11 Flammables: Alternative Release
The use of flammable materials at the City of Avenal WTP facility is not encompassed by either the federal or
state RMP requirements. Therefore, this section is not applicable.
The PHA was due January 2025 but was completed in February 2025 due to the latest consultant utilized for the facility's anniversary dates no
longer being in business resulting in unforeseen delays to the City.
